awd_titl_txt: Design and Testing of Math Models of Iron Trafficking and Regulation in Eukaryotes
awd_abstract_narration:
Iron is an essential micronutrient of eukaryotic cells. It is required to generate most of the chemical energy in our bodies. Iron-bound enzymes catalyze hundreds of reactions in cells, including processes as fundamental as DNA replication and repair. In this project, the principal investigator's aim is to develop mathematical models that simulate the movement of iron in eukaryotic cells and to investigate how that iron is regulated by cells. Like cars driving into a city at rush-hour, iron "traffic" occurs on different pathways in the main cytosol region of the cell, and different iron species end up at different locations in the cell such as in mitochondria, the nucleus, or other organelles. The cell regulates these traffic patterns so it can survive and prosper under various environmental situations (too much iron or too little iron). However, the details of this regulation - at the level of molecules - are poorly understood. In this project, the investigator's main objective is to develop a comprehensive math model that accounts for all of the iron-containing species in the cell that will help explain complex iron "traffic" within cells. As part of the broader impacts of the project, the PI will engage graduate and undergraduate students, including members of underrepresented groups in science, in interdisciplinary research training.  The PI will also develop a website offering free downloads, sample data and video tutorials related to the project. 

The overall objective of this project is to develop molecular-level mechanistically-based math models of iron trafficking and regulation that can simulate the comprehensive iron content and iron-based reactivity of a yeast cell. The PI will construct a model that accounts for iron in the cytosol, mitochondria, vacuoles, ER/Golgi, nuclei, and cell wall. The ordinary-differential-equations-based models will reflect all of the ca. 120 iron-containing species in yeast cells, with species being represented as groups of aggregated components. Models will share "housekeeping" processes but each model will have a unique emphasis that will be expanded in detail. In developing the models, the investigator will focus on: a) respiration and reactive oxygen species; b) cytosolic iron metabolism (involving the cytosolic iron sulfur cluster assembly (CIA) and iron-related chemistry in the nucleus; c) mitochondrial iron-sulfur and heme chemistry; d) nutrient iron import and metabolism; e) iron homeostasis and regulation. Each model will be optimized in terms of kinetic parameters against experimental data obtained in the PI's lab or elsewhere. Models will be tested by determining whether predictions made by the model (e.g. the effects of deleting or overexpressing a gene related to iron metabolism) are realized experimentally. Models will also guide the design of new experiments, generating a unique synergy between experiments and modeling that will advance our understanding of the cell biology of iron metabolism.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Objectives:     The overall objective of the project was to develop mathematical models that describe rates of iron trafficking and regulation in the simplest and best understood eukaryotic cell, Saccharomyces cerevisiae. These cells contain about 100 iron-containing proteins. We initially developed simple models and added complexity as additional experimental results were obtained. Solved models made predictions that were tested experimentally, and discrepancies were used to improve next-generation models. We focused on three cellular states, including healthy, iron-deficient, and mutant cells which mimicked the mitochondrial disease Friedreich's ataxia in humans.

 

Foundations and Frameworks: One aspect of the project was to define the iron-contents of the cell in quantitative terms. We compiled and organized published information regarding the anatomy of a cell, including volumes and dimensions of organelles and cellular spaces. We catalogued the concentrations of known iron-containing proteins and non-proteinaceous species in the cell, as well as the types of iron centers present in each. We compared Mossbauer spectra of whole cells and organelles to those predicted by this analysis. We developed an ordinary-differential-equations- (ODE-) based mathematical framework for modeling iron trafficking within in a growing eukaryotic cell.

 

Experimental Parameters:  A second aspect of the project was to obtain experimental results needed for model development. We primarily characterized the cytosolic labile iron pool in yeast cells, as little was known about it. This pool serves as the "grand central station" for iron trafficking and regulation. Upon entering the cell, nutrient iron enters the pool and is subsequently distributed to various cellular destinations. We isolated nuclei from cells and characterized their iron content. We collected numerous Mossbauer spectra of whole yeast cells and isolated organelles, in healthy, diseased, and iron-deficient states, to provide additional information for model development.

 

Models: These foundational aspects were used to build mathematical models of iron trafficking and regulation in growing yeast cells. As illustrated in Figure 1, nutrient iron is imported into the cytosol, where it becomes incorporated into the labile iron pool (called FC). Iron from this pool can enter vacuoles for storage or be converted into another group of cytosolic (and nuclear) iron proteins called the CIA. Pool iron can also enter mitochondria in which case it becomes part of the labile iron pool in that organelle, called FM. FM is a substrate for assembly of iron-sulfur-clusters and hemes, collectively called FS. FS becomes installed in the mitochondrial respiratory complexes, which then reduce O2 during respiration. Because of this, minimal O2 enters the mitochondrial matrix under healthy conditions, whereas more O2 enters under diseased conditions. According to the developed model, O2 that enters due to a weakened "Respiratory Shield" reacts with FM to generate iron nanoparticles and reactive oxygen species. These chemical reactions were translated into a set of ODEs which were solved, initially under steady-state conditions but eventually under time-dependent or dynamic ones.

In Fernandez et al. 2022, the steady-state model was solved using a standard approach. We added regulation as needed to simulate the phenotype of the diseased or iron-deficient state. In Thorat et al. (submitted) we employed more elegant mathematical procedures to solve the system. We also developed a new approach of understanding autoregulation of iron trafficking on the cellular level. Once solved, the model simulated how iron trafficking is affected when healthy cells become diseased or iron deficient. It also accurately predicted the healing effect of reducing the level of oxygen to which diseased cells are exposed.  The same approach could be applied to many other problems in cellular biochemistry.

The final model for this project, involving 169 reactions, 79 components, and 5 sub-compartments is under development. Absolute steady-state rates in units of microM/min for all reactions have been determined, but they must be adjusted. Then we will add autoregulation and solve the dynamical system.

Our results impact both computational systems' biology and the metabolism of iron in eukaryotic cells. Our models provide new insights into iron metabolism, and the mathematical tools developed can help solve other similar systems in rigorous and physically meaningful ways. The project helps bridge the barrier between those trained in mathematics vs. in biochemistry. Finally, the project may impact how medical doctors analyse and treat iron-related diseases. Doctors with a computer program in which any aspect of iron metabolism could be altered to mimic the diseased state of a patient, as developed in this project, could use it to diagnose problems in a more sophisticated manner because most or all interactions involving iron would be included. Simulations might suggest a blend of treatments and strategies to avoid side effects. Such programs do not exist, but the models developed here are a first-step in their development.
